Immunol. 2001; 166: 1206-1213Crossref PubMed Scopus (198) Google Scholar), and it has also been reported that PKCβ may modulate the respiratory burst of both neutrophils and HL-60 cells (13Majumdar S. Kane L.H. Rossi M.W. Volpp B.D. Nauseef W.M. Korchak H.M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1176: 276-286Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar, 14Korchak H.M. Rossi M.W. Kilpatrick L.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 27292-27299Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar). However, the contribution of each PKC isoform to the regulation of monocyte activation has not yet been elucidated. We have demonstrated that fMLP stimulates increased activity in RhoA, a small GTPase (15Huang S. Chen L-Y. Zuraw B.L. Ye R.D. Pan Z.K. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 40977-40981Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar), and that this activity in human peripheral blood monocytes is mediated by the guanine nucleotide exchange factor Lbc (16Chen L-Y. Zuraw B.L. Ye R.D. Pan Z.K. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 7208-7212Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar). We therefore investigated the role of PKC in the fMLP-stimulated signaling events that lead to the activation of NF-κB. We report that exposure of monocytes to fMLP causes increased activity of an nPKC isoform, PKCϵ, and that inhibition of PKCϵ activity blocks fMLP-stimulated activation of NF-κB. We also report that RhoA associates specifically with the PKCϵ in fMLP-stimulated monocytes and that the fMLP-induced PKCϵ activity is blocked by an inhibitor of RhoA. The results demonstrate that PKCϵ is a novel signal transducer for RhoA-mediated activation of NF-κB leading to proinflammatory cytokine gene expression in human peripheral blood monocytes stimulated with bacterial products. Reagents—fMLP and 1,25(OH)2D3 were obtained from Sigma. Staurosporine, Gö 6976, and PKCϵ inhibitor peptide were purchased from Calbiochem. Recombinant human TNFα was obtained from R & D Systems Inc (Minneapolis, MN). The cDNAs encoding the constitutively active mutant of PKCϵ and the dominant-negative mutants of PKCϵ and PKCα were cloned into the eukaryotic expression vector pEFneo. The dominant-negative IKKβ mutant and the recombinant Clostridium botulinum C3 transferase exoenzyme were obtained as described previously (17Chen L-Y. Zuraw B.L. Liu F.-T. Huang S. Pan Z.K. J. Immunol. 2002; 169: 3934-3939Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar). The polyclonal antibody against phospho-PKCϵ and monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) against RhoA, PKCϵ, and PKCα were purchased from Santa Cruz Biotechnology (Santa Cruz, CA). The polyclonal antibody against phospho-PKCα/β was purchased from Cell Signaling Technology (Beverly, MA). Preparation of Monocytes from Peripheral Blood—Heparinized human peripheral blood from healthy donors was fractionated on Percoll (Amersham Biosciences) density gradients. Mononuclear cells and neutrophils were obtained by centrifugation through a 55/74% discontinuous Percoll gradient. Monocytes were further separated from this population using gelatin/plasma-coated flasks (1Pan Z. Kravchenko V.V. Ye R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 7787-7790Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar). Monocytes were resuspended in RPMI 1640 medium (Irvine Scientific, Santa Ana, CA) containing 10% (v/v) heat-inactivated fetal bovine serum, penicillin (100 units/ml), streptomycin (100 μg/ml), and l-glutamine (2 mm; Irvine Scientific). Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay (EMSA)—Nuclear extracts were prepared from human peripheral blood monocytes using the method of Dignam et al. (18Dignam J.D. Lebovitz R.M. Roeder R.G. Nucleic Acids Res. 1983; 11: 1475-1489Crossref PubMed Scopus (9131) Google Scholar). The electrophoretic mobility shift assay was performed using 2.5 μg of the nuclear extract as described previously (2Kravchenko V.V. Pan Z. Han J. Herbert J-M. Ulevitch R.J. Ye R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 14928-14934Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (157) Google Scholar). Immunoprecipitation and Immunoblotting—Monocyte lysates were incubated with an appropriate amount of antibody for 3 h and then precipitated following absorption onto protein A-Sepharose (Amersham Biosciences). Precipitates were washed three times, separated by SDS-PAGE, and transferred to Hybond-ECL nitrocellulose (Amersham Biosciences). Filter strips were incubated with primary antibody for 30 min at room temperature, followed by addition of peroxidase-conjugated IgG (1:10,000 dilution, 30 min) and then analyzed for peroxidase using enhanced chemiluminescence reagents (PerkinElmer Life Science). Detection of Phosphorylated PKCs—Monocytes were incubated in medium ± fMLP then lysed in Laemmli buffer. Equal volumes of the lysates from each condition were resolved by SDS-PAGE using 8% gels and transferred to Hybond-ECL nitrocellulose membranes. The membranes were initially probed with a polyclonal anti-phospho PKC antibody (Cell Signaling Technology) that at a dilution of 1:2000 detects activated forms of cPKCα/β. A 1:200 dilution of anti-PKCϵ antibody was used at the same time to detect the nPKCϵ isoform. Membranes then were stripped and incubated with a murine anti-PKCα or murine anti-PKCϵ mAb. Transfection of Cells with PKC-specific siRNA and Luciferase Activity Assay—Short interfering RNA was used to reduce PKC levels in THP1 cells. 21-mer siRNA sequences with a dTdT-3′ overhang (Qiagen-Xeragon, Germantown, MD) specific for PKCα (5′-AAGCACAAGTTCAAAATCCAC-3′) or PKCϵ (5′-AAGCCCCTAAAGACAATGAAG-3′) were purchased. THP1 cells were co-transfected with either a PKCα-siRNA or a PKCϵ-siRNA together with the NF-κB-dependent luciferase reporter plasmid (pNF-κB-LUC). The reporter construct NF-κB-LUC was generated as described (19Shapiro V.S. Mollenauer M.N. Greene W.C. Weiss A. J. Exp. Med. 1996; 184: 1663-1669Crossref PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar). The plasmid pCMVβ (Clontech) was used as a control for transfection efficiency, and this was monitored via the expression of β-galactosidase. THP1 cells were differentiated by incubation with 1,25(OH)2D3 for 3 days (20Mackman N. Brand K. Edgington T.S. J. Exp. Med. 1991; 174: 1517-1526Crossref PubMed Scopus (329) Google Scholar) and then transiently transfected with plasmids using diethyl aminoethyl (DEAE)-dextran. The transfected cells were cultivated for 48 h before a 6-h incubation in medium ± 100 nm fMLP. Luciferase activity was determined by using the luciferase assay kit (Promega) and a Monolight 2010 luminometer (Analytical Luminescence, San Diego, CA). fMLP-induced NF-κB Activation Is Blocked by a PKC Inhibitor—To assess the role of PKC in fMLP-induced NF-κB activation, we examined the consequences of preincubating cells with specific PKC inhibitors. Staurosporine is a specifically inhibitor of PKC. It inhibits cPKC and nPKC but not aPKC isozymes (21Marte B.M. Meyer T. Stabel S. Standke G.J.R. Jaken S. Fabbro D. Hynes N.E. Cell Growth & Differ. 1994; 5: 239-247PubMed Google Scholar, 22Seynaeve C.M. Kazanietz M.G. Blumberg P.M. Sausville E.A. Worland P.J. Mol. Pharmacol. 1994; 45: 1207-1214PubMed Google Scholar). Following pretreatment ±50 nm staurosporine for 15 min, human monocytes were stimulated with fMLP or TNFα for 60 min, and the activation of NF-κB was assessed by electrophoretic mobility shift assay. In the absence of an inhibitor, the DNA binding activity of NF-κB was strongly induced by both fMLP and TNFα (Fig. 1A, lanes 2 and 3). This activation was largely prevented in those monocytes pretreated with staurosporine that were subsequently exposed to fMLP (Fig. 1A, lane 5). In contrast, the staurosporine treatment only marginally affected TNFα-induced activation of NF-κB (Fig. 1A, lane 6). Because staurosporine inhibits both cPKC and nPKC activity, we next examined which of these was required for fMLP-induced activation of NF-κB. Although pretreatment of monocytes with Gö 6976, an inhibitor of cPKC (PKCα and -β), did not significantly inhibit NF-κB activation (Fig. 1B, lanes 5 and 6), the pretreatment with a PKCϵ inhibitory peptide suppressed the activation of NF-κB in fMLP-stimulated monocytes (Fig. 1C, lane 5) suggesting a role for PKCϵ. In contrast, neither a PKCα/β-specific inhibitory peptide nor a nonsense control peptide had any effect (data not shown). fMLP Induces Activation of PKCϵ and PKCα/β in Human Blood Monocytes—Because inhibition of PKCϵ activity abrogated fMLP-induced NF-κB activation, we next examined whether fMLP induced PKCϵ activation, as PKCs play a key role in intracellular signal processes linked to diverse receptor types. As PKCϵ is activated through phosphorylation of a carboxyl-terminal hydrophobic site (Ser-729), which increases the kinase activity up to 80-fold (23Parekh D. Ziegler W. Yonezawa K. Hara K. Parker P.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 34758-34764Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (162) Google Scholar), we were able to use an antibody that strictly recognizes Ser-729-phosphorylated PKCϵ to detect the activation of PKCϵ. Following stimulation with fMLP, monocytes were lysed, and the lysates (20 μg) were analyzed for phosphorylation of PKC by using a Western blot. Exposure to fMLP led to a time-dependent increase in phosphorylation of PKCϵ that was seen within 10 min and peaked after 10-20 min (Fig. 2A). This phosphorylation was not as rapid as that that seen for the fMLP-induced phosphorylation of PKCα/β, which was largely complete within 5 min (Fig. 2B). PKCϵ but Not PKCα Is Needed for fMLP-induced Activation of NF-κB—The necessity of PKCϵ for fMLP-induced activation of NF-κB was further demonstrated by overexpressing a dominant-negative form of PKCϵ in THP1 cells. Cells were co-transfected with expression vectors encoding either a dominant-negative PKCα or a dominant-negative PKCϵ together with the NF-κB-dependent luciferase reporter plasmid (pNF-κB-LUC) and then exposed to fMLP. Dominant-negative protein expression was confirmed by immunoblotting using anti-PKC antibodies (data not shown). Fig. 3 shows that expression of the dominant-negative PKCϵ mutant protein was associated with poor induction of luciferase activity promoted by NF-κB (Fig. 3A, lane 6). In contrast, the expression of a dominant-negative PKCα did not have this effect (Fig. 3A, lane 4). To further confirm the role of PKCα and PKCϵ in fMLP-induced NF-κB activation. The effect of siRNA on PKC expression was quantified by immunoblotting cells 96 h posttransfection. Although none of the PKC isoform-specific siRNA sequences affected the expression of β-tubulin, PKCα expression was reduced by PKCα-siRNA to 59.25 ± 6.18% and PKCϵ-siRNA reduced expression of PKCϵ to 67.27 ± 5.78% of the amounts found in cells transfected with control RNA (Fig. 3B). The PKC-siRNA-transfected cells were then exposed to fMLP. Here, PKCϵ-siRNA reduced NF-κB activity, whereas PKCα siRNA had no effect (Fig. 3C). These results confirmed that PKCϵ activity was required for fMLP-induced activation of NF-κB. Although fMLP exposure led to increased PKCα activity, this appeared not to be required for the activation of NF-κB. Rather, PKCα activity may be involved in the respiratory burst or chemotaxis both of which would be induced by fMLP (13Majumdar S. Kane L.H. Rossi M.W. Volpp B.D. Nauseef W.M. Korchak H.M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1176: 276-286Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar, 14Korchak H.M. Rossi M.W. Kilpatrick L.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 27292-27299Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar, 24Gomez-Cambronero J. Molski T.F. Becker E.L. Sha'afi R.I. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1987; 148: 38-46Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar, 25Merritt J.E. Greener M Hallam T.J. Swayne G.T. Cell. Signal. 1991; 3: 73-77Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). PKCϵ Signals fMLP-induced Activation NF-κB Activation via IκB Kinase (IKK)β—We previously found that fMLP induced the degradation of IκBα in human blood monocytes (5Pan Z.K. Chen L-Y. Cochrane C.G. Zuraw B.L. J. Immunol. 2000; 164: 404-411Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar). This degradation is required for the activation NF-κB and requires IκBα to be phosphorylated by IKKβ. We therefore sought to determine the involvement of IKKβ in the fMLP-induced activation of NF-κB. THP1 cells were co-transfected with NF-κB-LUC in combination with a plasmid encoding a dominant-negative mutant of IKKβ, which was provided by Dr. Frank Mercurio (Signal Transduction, San Diego, CA). This dominant-negative mutant largely prevented the activation of NF-κB (Fig. 4A, lane 4) indicating a requirement for IKKβ in the response. We also addressed the function of IKKβ in PKCϵ-mediated activation of NF-κB. Although expression of the constitutively active form of PKCϵ induces NF-κB activity in the absence of fMLP, this NF-κB activity was not found when these cells were also co-transfected with a plasmid encoding the dominant-negative IKKβ (Fig. 4B, lane 3). Thus, it appears that PKCϵ mediates its effects via the activation of IKKβ. PKCϵ Interacts with RhoA in fMLP-stimulated Monocytes—We previously demonstrated that fMLP stimulates the activity of RhoA, a small GTPase and that this activity in monocytes is required for the activation of NF-κB induced by fMLP (15Huang S. Chen L-Y. Zuraw B.L. Ye R.D. Pan Z.K. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 40977-40981Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). We therefore tested whether the functional interaction between PKCϵ and RhoA was important for this fMLP-induced activation of NF-κB. We examined whether the biological activity of the PKCϵ in human peripheral blood monocytes was based on its ability to interact with low molecular weight GTP-binding proteins and whether PKCϵ was functional when binding to RhoA GTPase in vivo. Monocytes (10 × 106) were exposed to medium ± 100 nm fMLP (37 °C, 10 min) and then lysed. Anti-RhoA antibody was used to immunoprecipitate the RhoA GTPase from the lysates, and the components of the immunoprecipitates were detected by immunoblotting with antibodies specific for PKCϵ or PKCα. Only PKCϵ was detected as a co-precipitate with RhoA (Fig. 5). In control experiments, we preincubated the anti-RhoA antibody with blocking peptides before adding it to cell lysates. The blocking peptides eliminated the formation of an immunoprecipitate containing PKCϵ (Fig. 5, lanes 3). These data showed that PKCϵ binds to the RhoA GTPase. PKCϵ Acts as a Signaling Component Downstream of RhoA— The results presented above demonstrated that there was an interaction between PKCϵ and RhoA in monocytes after their exposure to fMLP. We next examined whether RhoA mediated the activation of NF-κB via a downstream effect on PKCϵ. This question was addressed by using C. botulinum C3 transferase, which is an exotoxin that inhibits the Rho GTPases (RhoA, -B, and -C) but does not inhibit Rac nor Cdc42 GTPases (26Aktories K. J. Clin. Investig. 1997; 99: 827-829Crossref PubMed Scopus (147) Google Scholar). Following incubation with or without 10 μg/ml recombinant C3 transferase for 16 h, human monocytes were stimulated with fMLP for 10 min, and PKCϵ activity was assessed. As shown in Fig. 6A, the PKCϵ activity was significantly inhibited by C3 transferase, indicating that PKCϵ is a signaling component that becomes activated downstream of RhoA. The relationship between RhoA activity and subsequent PKCϵ activation was further investigated using THP1 cells that had been co-transfected with expression vectors encoding a constitutively active form of RhoA (Fig. 6B, lanes 2-4) and either a dominant-negative PKCϵ (lane 3) or a dominant-negative PKCα (lane 4) together with an NF-κB-dependent luciferase reporter plasmid. The constitutively active RhoA induced a strong luciferase activity, but this activity was inhibited by co-expression of the dominant-negative PKCϵ (Fig. 6B, lane 3), whereas co-expression of the dominant-negative PKCα had no effect (Fig. 6B, lane 4). These results confirm that RhoA activity is required for the activation of PKCϵ induced by fMLP and that PKCϵ acts as a signaling component downstream of RhoA. We previously demonstrated that fMLP stimulates small GTPase RhoA activity in monocytes, and this activity is required for the activation of NF-κB that is induced by fMLP (15Huang S. Chen L-Y. Zuraw B.L. Ye R.D. Pan Z.K. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 40977-40981Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). In the present study, we have demonstrated that PKCϵ is a signaling component downstream of RhoA and mediates the fMLP-induced activation of NF-κB in human peripheral blood monocytes. We employed multiple approaches to establish the role of PKCϵ in fMLP-induced activation of NF-κB in monocytes as PKCϵ has not previously been implicated in the signaling pathway. Exposure of monocytes to fMLP stimulated a time-dependent increase in phosphorylation of PKCϵ and preincubation of the monocytes with staurosporine or PKCϵ inhibitory peptide significantly inhibited the fMLP-induced activation of NF-κB. The requirement for phosphorylation of PKCϵ was then confirmed by co-transfecting THP1 cells with either plasmids encoding dominant-negative forms of PKCϵ and PKCα or short interfering RNA to reduce the expression of PKCϵ and PKCα. Because there was only partial inhibition of NF-κB activity, both after incubation with PKCϵ inhibitory peptide and by expression of dominant-negative PKCϵ, it is possible that other nPKC isoforms, such as PKCδ and PKCθ, are also involved in fMLP-induced signaling, because PKCδ and PKCθ can activate NF-κB (10Lin X. O'Mahony A. Mu Y. Geleziunas R. Greene W.C. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2000; 20: 2933-2940Crossref PubMed Scopus (230) Google Scholar, 11Rahman A. Anwar K.N. Uddin S. Xu N. Ye R.D. Platanias L.C. Malik A.B. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2001; 21: 5554-5565Crossref PubMed Scopus (147) Google Scholar). The finding that PKCϵ was critical to the activation of NF-κB led us to address its role in fMLP-induced signaling in monocytes. Despite an apparent role of the Rho GTPases in cytokine gene expression, relatively little is known about the intracellular signaling pathways linking RhoA activation to cytokine gene transcription in leukocytes. The Rho family of small G-proteins has been shown to activate several serine/threonine kinases, which can mediate downstream effects. These appear mainly to act on the actin cytoskeleton. Naumann and colleagues (27Foryst-Ludwig A. Naumann M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 39779-39785Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar) reported that p21-activating kinase 1, the immediate downstream effector of Rac1 and Cdc42, bound and activated NF-κB-inducing kinase, leading to degradation of IκB and increasing the binding of NF-κB to DNA in gastric epithelial cells infected by Helicobacter pylori. Furthermore, Frost et al. (28Frost J.A. Swantek J.L. Stippec S. Yin M.J. Gaynor R. Cobb M.H. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 19693-19699Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar) showed that a constitutively active p21-activating kinase 1 stimulated NF-κB activity in fibroblasts and macrophages, and that activation of p21-activating kinase 1 was required for the stimulation of NF-κB activity both by Rac1 in fibroblasts and following exposure of mouse macrophages to lipopolysaccharide. These results suggest that p21-activating kinase 1 may play a role in the activation of NF-κB and the induction of inflammatory cytokine expression mediated by both Rac1 and Cdc42 but not by RhoA. Activated RhoA has been shown to be involved in phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase-mediated activation of PKC in a murine T cell line and HEK 293 cells (29Flynn P. Mellor H. Casamassima A. Parker P.J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 11064-11070Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). Recently, several studies have indicated the role of PKCϵ in mitogen-activate protein kinase activation and in NF-κB activation in macrophages activated by bacterial products (9Castrillo A. Pennington D.J. Otto F. Parker P.J. Owen M.J. Boscá L. J. Exp. Med. 2001; 194: 1231-1242Crossref PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar, 30Aksoy E. Amraoui Z. Goriely S. Goldman M. Willems F. Eur. J. Immunol. 2002; 32: 3040-3049Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar, 31Valledor A.F. Xaus J. Comalada M. Soler C. Celada A. J. Immunol. 2000; 164: 29-37Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). Our data suggest that fMLP activates PKCϵ in human peripheral blood monocytes, and this activation provides a signal acting downstream of GTPase RhoA that mediates fMLP-induced NF-κB activation. We determined the mechanisms by which PKCϵ and its downstream effector, IκB kinase, contributed to NF-κB activity. Studies have shown that NF-κB activity is primarily regulated at the level of IκB degradation, which is accomplished through serine phosphorylation of IκB (Ser-32 and Ser-36) by IKK (32Delhase M. Hayakawa M. Chen Y. Karin M. Science. 1999; 284: 309-313Crossref PubMed Scopus (741) Google Scholar, 33Li Q. Van Antwerp D. Mercurio F. Lee K-F. Verma I.M. Science. 1999; 284: 321-325Crossref PubMed Scopus (847) Google Scholar). We observed that expression of a dominant-negative form of IKKβ prevented the development of NF-κB activity induced both by fMLP and by the expression of a constitutively active form of PKCϵ. Although we found that IKKβ is required for PKCϵ-mediated NF-κB activation induced by fMLP, the underlying mechanism is yet to be defined. One possible mechanism is that PKCϵ may phosphorylate IKKβ directly. This suggestion is supported by the observation that PKCζ, an atypical isoform of PKC, directly phosphorylates IKKβ in vitro and physically associates with IKKβ in 293 cells (34Lallena M.J. Diaz-Meco M.T. Bren G. Paya C.V. Moscat J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 2180-2188Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). However, we have been unable to detect a physical association between PKCϵ and the IKK complexes (data not shown). An alternative explanation is that PKCϵ may indirectly activate IKK through one or more intermediate components. One such signaling intermediate might be MEKK1, which has been implicated in the T cell receptor signaling pathway whereby CD3-CD28 co-stimulation leads to the activation of NF-κB through selective activation of IKKβ (35Kempiak S.J. Hiura T.S. Nel A.E. J. Immunol. 1999; 162: 3176-3187PubMed Google Scholar). In summary, we have shown that fMLP stimulates the activation of PKCϵ in monocytes. Utilizing both specific inhibitors as well as transient expression of a dominant-negative PKCϵ mutant or PKCϵ siRNA, we found that the fMLP-induced activation of NF-κB required PKCϵ activity. Furthermore, we have shown that PKCϵ associates functionally with the RhoA in fMLP-stimulated monocytes and that the PKCϵ activation induced by fMLP is inhibited by a specific RhoA inhibitor, C3 transferase, suggesting that RhoA likely functions upstream of PKCϵ in the signaling pathway. These findings provide evidence that fMLP-induced activation of NF-κB utilizes a signaling pathway that requires the activity of PKCϵ. The RhoA GTPase-PKCϵ-NF-κB pathway appears to play a central role in the leukocyte response to chemoattractant and is likely to be important in host defense and inflammation. We thank Drs. J. Han, F. Mercurio, and G. M. Bokoch, for providing DNA constructs and for their helpful discussions of this manuscript.

The poet's vividly imagined flight unwittingly captures a physical law of motion. The beautifully preserved skull pictured on the left is from Dmanisi in the republic of Georgia, a site that has already yielded archaeological evidence for the presence of early Homo outside Africa 1.77 million years ago. The notable thing about the new find is its teeth, or rather its tooth. This individual lost all but one tooth some years before death. He or she may have eaten soft plant and animal foods that didn't require heavy chewing — or perhaps other individuals in the social group gave support beyond that offered by non-human primates. In 1632, Galileo described his experience of motion aboard a large ship1,2 and exposed in detail the invariance principle, which was then rightly named after him. I suggest that more than three centuries earlier, in The Divine Comedy, his fellow countryman Dante Alighieri intuitively grasped what Galileo was later to establish as one of the pillars of modern science.
